A cream colour net blouse with short sleeves and decorated by pleated embroidery and clear glass buttons. The blouse belonged to the donor's Great Grandmother.
This silver tea strainer features a perforated clamshell-style infusing mechanism on a hinge. On the reverse is stamped "Heirloom plate, Patented Nov. 21, 1922."
BLUE WOOL TOP WITH GREEN BAND, BLACK LEATHER VISOR WITH GOLD BRAID, RCDC CAP BADGE Equipment of Lt. Col. Mc Parks Rcdc
This is a dark, khaki twill tube that was used to slip over a shirt or coat shoulder strap. Lt. Col. Crown are embroidered onto dark green wool.
This is a gold cord in a compound figure eight weave. It was worn on the shoulder of the number one dress.

A unique bamboo turned dining room chair with upholstered seat. The seat has been covered by a cloth covering with floral design. The bamboo gives the chair a unique look with black and gold bands at each joint. This chair belonged to Ralph Clench (See person link).
A unique bamboo turned dining chair with upholstered seat. The chair has been painted black and has a floral seat cover. This chair belonged to Ralph Clench (See person link).
This is a small, round tin container with a number of steel rivets inside. There is white paper on top of the container and was part of a collection of tools owned by John Swinton.
This is a white crucible with a grey rim from the tools of John Swinton. It reads 'COORS US 000" on the outside.
Girl's brown leather, ankle-strap boots are bound in soft brown cotton. Single button closure, scalloped leather toe medallions.  The brown leather soles are engraved with a maple twig motif.

A pair of ladies ankle strap shoes made of grey-blue leather with rectangular decorative inserts and 2-button closure. "Paris 1925" is handwritten on each sole and the makers stamp is found on the inside, "Chaussures Raoul, Paris. 17B rue de la Madeleine".  French soldier Roger Trentesaux remembered passing the Raoul Show Store and seeing its windows blown out during the liberation of Paris in 1944.
A pair of child's maccasin-style slippers of soft cream leather with silk ribbon binding, medallions and ties. The number 4270 4 is printed on the interior in blue.

A brown satin suit jacket and skirt. The jacket has pleats at the top and is decorated with a rosette in the front; the rosette has four ribbons moving diagonally downward. The collar and cuff are lined with white lace, which adds nice contrast. The jacket is fastened with eleven buttons down the front. The skirt is a plain brown satin.

A cotton bonnet with satin ribbons, decorated with feathers and plastic beads. The bonnet is black with two black feathers across the front. The beads decorate the bottom boarder of the bonnet. The bonnet is from the estate of Jeanett Webster.
A christening gown consisting of a plain white cotton underdress with cotton lace at the bottom and a white cotton overdress with lace at the neck and around the cuffs.

A women's suit consisting of an overdress made of black linen with ribbon trim and an underdress skirt of thin brown cotton with black linen-like material around the botton. A main bodice with a main colour of black and a cream coloured lace collar and two bands of black ribbon placed vertically on the front and back. Lastly a sash made of linen and ribbon with hooks at each end to fasten around the waist.

A lady's suit considting of two parts, firstly a top bodice made of yellow cotton with purple ribbon, beige lace, and seven bows down the front. Second, a cotton yellow skirt with pleats in the front and a decorative purple ribbon along the bottom. The skirt fastens with hooks at the back.

This musket, circa 1800, is a Brown Bess an "India Pattern" design. The ram rod is missing and there is a make-do front sling swivel. The stock is cracked and the proper right side on the bottom extends from the front of feather springs to the trigger guard. There is an engraving, "TOWER" which suggests the musket is from the British Tower of London arsenal. There are also small engravings of a Hanoverian crown and a "GR" cipher.

This bayonet would have been designed to fit on the muzzle of a rifle or musket barrel, making it into a close range weapon.  There is a marking on the blade that has a triangular-like symbol with a "3" below. A bayonet would have arguably been on every soldier's firearm during the War of 1812-1814.

An 1822 Pattern Infantry Officer's Sword. The sword guard is gilt brass with a small hinged section and presents a Victoria cypher. The grip is made of shark skin and bound with braided copper wire. The blade is a pipe back with etched Victoria cypher. This sword belonged to Lt. Col Philip, 5th Lincoln Militia.

An Artillery Officer's Sword made by Wiersburg Kirshbaum of Solingen, Germany. The blade is marked with Edward the Seventh cyphers. The number "16177" is stamped into the edge of the blade. A brown leather sword knot accompanies the sword.
See full description in Related Record, "Sword - 993.362.1(A)".
For full description see Related Record, "Sword - 993.362.1(A)".
For full description see Related Record, "Sword - 993.362.1(A)".

This steel bayonet would have been designed to fit on the muzzle of a rifle or musket barrel, making it into a close range weapon. There are no visible identifying marks but it is the proper size and shape of an early 19th century British bayonet. A bayonet would have arguably been on every soldier's firearm during the War of 1812-1814.

A small guitar with griction peg tuners in a black case. The bridge has been moved and a metal tail piece has been added. The maker label is on the inside of the guitar and is, "J. A. Rohe, Paris". The guitar is from the Rogers, Blake, Harrison Collection.

A black beaver finished top hat with black silk ribbion. The inside is lined with white silk-like material and stamped with the makers mark, "J.H. Rogers Toronto Ont. - Extra Quality". There is writing on the inside in black ink that reads, "Blake / Niagara-on-the-Lake, Ontario". The top hat is from the Rogers, Blake, Harrison Collection.

From the Rogers, Blake, Harrison Collection. A pair of men's worn shovel-toe shoes with brass-bound eyelets and punch-cut detail on vamp edging.  "Mr. Blake" is written on the inside of each shoe in black ink.

A brown leather hatbox for a black top hat. It is a haped case, lined with a blue patterned cotton. Signed on the side is the name, "John A. Blake, Niagara Canada West". The hatbox is from the Rogers, Blake, Harrison Collection.

After the Civil War, a body of Irish-American veterans sought to obtain Irish independence from Great Britain, and believed that by capturing Canada, they could achieve this. Known as the Fenian Brotherhood, these radicals conducted raids into Canadian territory from 1866 to 1871 and although they had initial success, it would prove short lived. The movement ended in failure and was over by 1871. The only Fenian victory was the initial assault at Ridgeway in 1866, all subsequent actions were failures. Large bodies of British troops and Canadian militia defended the Canadian border and stopped the Fenians before they could gain a foothold in Canada.John Raynor of Niagara-on-the-Lake was one of the many Canadian veterans who were awarded this medal for service in 1870. Raynor had initially volunteered under the 1854 Canadian Militia Act and served in the army after the Trent Affair, when an American vessel captured Confederate diplomats from a British mail packet, creating severe tension between Britain and America during the Civil War. The Trent Affair encouraged Britain to increase the military presence in Canadian territory. Raynor's service throughout all of these incidents reflects a great deal of Canada's experience in the mid- 19th Century. It also illuminates the Canadian involvement in the American Civil War. The medal is a testament to Raynor's long service in the defense of Canadian territory.

A commemorative medal given to Lewis Arthur Warner for service during the First World War. The front has a man on a horse and is inscribed with "1914â€”1918", while the back is inscribed with "GEORGIS V BRITT OMN REX ET IND IMP".

This conical .55 calibre lead bullet features an iron cup at the base, which was thrust ahead when fired, expanding the bullet against the rifling. This type of ammunition was known as a minie ball. The conical bullet, or Minie Ball, was invented in 1848 and recolutionized weaponry. Unlike the traditional ball, the Minie Ball expanded within the barrel of the musket in which it was fired, allowing them to take advantage of rifling that conventional musket balls could not. This dramatically increased the power and accuracy of the weapon. During the Fenian Raid, both Canadian Militia and Fenians fired these bullets from rifled muskets.

This souvenir teaspoon features a wavy handle and bowl with a depiction of cartoon characters known as Brownies, which were created by Canadian illustrator and author Palmer Cox. The bowl of the spoon  is engraved "Souvenir Traveler's Home. 8-9-10 1894 Geo. R. Andrews SR." "The Brownies" is engraved on the reverse of the handle. The Brownies was published in magazines and books during the late 19th century and early 20th century. At the peak of their popularity, the Brownies were a pioneering name brand within merchandising.

This souvenir teaspoon features an image of a beaver on the handle, a portrait of a man and "General French" written below the image with two crossed flags. On the reverse the spoon is marked "RC CO" and features crossing maple leaves.
This silver plate teaspoon is stamped on the reverse "Pat. Mar 2-15" and is hallmarked "1881 Rogers A1".
This silver plated teaspoon features a swirling floral pattern handle and is hallmarked on the reverse "Pat. Feb 9 - Silver plate A1".

This silver teaspoon features a floral border design and is engraved "Queens Royal", in reference to the Queen's Royal Hotel which used to be located on the shore of Lake Ontario in Niagara-on-the-Lake. It is hallmarked "1835 R. Wallace" on the reverse.
This silver fiddle-style teaspoon features a flat handle and is hallmarked "C. Culver" on the reverse.

This silver teaspoon feautres the Shriners symbol, the freemason symbol of the square and compass and a maltese cross with "In Hoc Signo Vinces" inscribed. The reverse is marked "Standard" and "Pat. Feb 9".
This silver teaspoon is marked on the reverse "Pat Mar 2-15 -1881 Rogers A1".
Child's dark purple/brown metallic sheen boot with 4-button closure. The inside is lined with red leather interior binding and stamped with "Size 3".

Quilted carriage slippers of black silk with pink satin lining c. 1870-1890. The shoes were designed by John Barker, 1892, he operated of of the largest and most prestigious emporiums in London, employing 1000 staff and showcasing an assortment of high-quality goods, many purchased at the Paris exhibitions.
Orange satin ball slipper c. 1890, with two-inch, copper-coloured heel and rhinestone toe adornment.  "Jackie" is handwritten in black ink on the white leather interior of one shoe.
A pink satin slipper with baby Louis heel and white kid lining. The shoe is marked "Geo T. Slater and Son" (stamped in gold on the insole).  May have been a wedding shoe as only one was preserved.

A pair of black leather shoes with pointed toe and stacked wooden heel c. 1910. The inside heel is stamped, "Class Gett". These shoes were worn by Florence Hutchison of Virgil, St. David's, and Queenston.
This is a hand sewn parchment envelope with "Ralfe Clench" written on the front.

A Sergeant Major's uniform coat of the Canadian 2nd Dragoons. The coat is made of blue wool with white wool lining and white wool epaulets covered with chain mail. The coat has two breast pockets with chevron flaps and a single button. The other seven hollow buttons are plated and have the word "Canada" across the top with a royal crown and maple leaf. On the collar are brass, oval insignia with Brock's Monument, and the words "2nd Dragoons" across the top. The right sleeve hosts chevrons and a crown insignia.

This is an Orange Lodge sash made from a blue ribbon and an orange ribbon along the edges. There is a blue rosette at the shoulder section and various symbols in white satin and silver lace decorate the sash. Symbols include a crown, a bible, a lodge symbol, a five point star, and a ladder.  The sash is attributed to Mr. Fred McCusker of Virgil, Ontario. Janet Carnochan, the Niagara Historical Society' former President and a curator, mentions in her "Historical Note #277" newspaper article that Mr. McCusker fought with the 2nd Canadian Contingent during the Boer War (1899-1902). His military records from that war state that he enlisted on December 30th, 1899 at the age of 22 years in St. Catharines, Ontario.  He was later discharged on January, 10th, 1901.  Mr. McCusker was a farmer by trade and belonged to the Church of England. His records indicate that he was born in Waterford, Ireland, had light-hair, blue eyes, was "clean shaven" and measured 5' 9" in height. He formerly belonged to the 2nd Dragoons. During the war he served in the 47th Regiment and received the Queen's (Queens) Medal with 5 clasps: Johannesburg, Diamond Hill, Belfast, Cape Colony and Orange Free State.

Brown leather, knee high gaiters with a front opening. They are closed by lacing. Marks on the inside include: "12 1/2, 14 1/2, 307".These gaiters are attributed to Mr. Fred McCusker of Virgil, Ontario. Janet Carnochan, the Niagara Historical Society' former President and a curator, mentions in her "Historical Note #277" newspaper article that Mr. McCusker fought with the 2nd Canadian Contingent during the Boer War (1899-1902). His military records from that war state that he enlisted on December 30th, 1899 at the age of 22 years in St. Catharines, Ontario.  He was later discharged on January, 10th, 1901.  Mr. McCusker was a farmer by trade and belonged to the Church of England. His records indicate that he was born in Waterford, Ireland, had light-hair, blue eyes, was "clean shaven" and measured 5' 9" in height. He formerly belonged to the 2nd Dragoons. During the war he served in the 47th Regiment and received the Queen's (Queens) Medal with 5 clasps: Johannesburg, Diamond Hill, Belfast, Cape Colony and Orange Free State.

A blue wool pillbox hat with heavy gold ribbon around base and elaborate gold braid knot on the top. The inside is lined in heavy brown cotton and is marked in red, "108" or "801" and in yellow "No. 11.". The makers stamp, "Christys' London" is also found inside.

This is a quilt patch with brown embroidered edging. The edging is finished with blanket stitching. Embroidered on a cream, cotton square is a woman in a blue dress standing in a garden. Pink, blue, and yellow flowers are embroidered onto the patch.

Rosette of the Niagara Sleigh Club. The rules of the club state that a blue rosette and red neck cloth were the club colours.Trying to make winter more enjoyable, this club began in 1838. They convened every Tuesday and Friday at 11 o'clock in Queenston.  Tuesday's were to be Ladies Day. Sadly, they disbanded by 1840.
A wooden cane style child's rocking chair with blue velvet seat and back and six decorative posts. The wood is stained a dark brown. This chair was likely machine made near the turn of the century.

A doll made of porcelain (head, hands, feet) and cloth stuffed body. The head has painted black hair and blue eyes, the feet are also painted brown with white socks and blue bows. The doll is dressed in flannel bloomers and a white muslin dress with lace accents. A matching bonnet with pink tie sits on the dolls head. This doll belonged to Pheobe Arnold of Queenston, who was born 1890.
One of five fragments of  various sized musket balls. Small and flattened on both sides from impact.

The First World War is an arresting demonstration of the conflict between traditional tactics and new technology. Commanders ordered soldiers to dig trenches to hold ground, and charge the enemy head on in order to advance. Facing newly developed machine guns, fighter planes and tanks, this policy led to an unprecedented number of casualties for both sides. In the spring of 1915, at the Second Battle of Ypres, allied soldiers would be introduced to yet another technological development: Chlorine Gas. At 5:00PM on April 22nd 1915, German troops released Chlorine gas on the French 45th Algerian Division, positioned to the left of the Canadian line at Ypres. While most of the gas missed the Canadians, the French retreat created a large gap in the defensive line that had to be filled by the outnumbered Canadians. Fighting to hold the position, the Canadians faced a direct Chlorine Gas attack two days later. Though the Canadians were able to hold the position until reinforcements arrived, the battle cost the lives of 6,000 Canadians in their first major engagement of the war. It was in this environment that the first gas masks were produced.The threat of poison gas remained, and different methods of protecting soldiers from Chemical warfare were developed. Featured here is a German Lederschutzmaske from 1917. It is composed of an all-leather face piece, glass lenses, and rubber and cloth straps which run along the back to ensure a secure fit. The chemical filter is directly attached, differentiating it from the Allied 'small box respirator' style of mask in which the filter was carried in a satchel, worn on the back and away from the face.  The German design made the mask less cumbersome, but it was known to reduce the soldier's ability to fire his weapon accurately.  Respirators on the mask were also known to wear out faster than their Allied counterparts, and the leather sections, used due to economic shortages, often failed under high concentrations of gas.     Although details of this mask's journey are unknown, it is likely that it made its way to Canada as part of a collection of war souvenirs. Trophies of the conflict were in great demand, with soldiers searching for weapons, clothing and equipment, to bring back as mementos of their actions overseas. Nearly 100 years later, souvenirs such as this one still serve as solemn reminders of the sacrifices that were made and of the challenges that Canadian soldiers faced during the conflict.

From the Servos Collection. A wrought iron circular trivet on three legs. A trivet was used to hold hot pots or cauldrons that had come out of the fire and on to the table or floor.Another trivet from the collection: FA69.3.115

From the Servos Collection. A steelyard balance uses counter weight to calculate the weight of the object hanging on the hooks. This steelyard is number 80 to 300, has two hanging hooks and a vase-shaped weight. It has the manufactures name, "P. ROGERS, WARRENTED".

From the Servos Collection. A cast iron waffle maker. The waffle maker has a hasp on the handle and a star design on the squares (for batter). There are marks, "6 A (?)".Another waffle maker in the collection: FA69.3.273

A iron trivet from the Servos Collection. This wrought iron trivet has a wooden handle and three legs. The triangular shape houses an inner part that can turn to each side. There are eight circular scroll arms giving the trivet a unique style. Trivets were used as a type of hot plate to support the bottom of a pot that has been taken out of the fire.

From the Servos Collection. A crimping iron set, fixed to a large oblong wooden base. This iron was used to make ruffles on shirts, etc. The two fluted iron rollers were turned by the circular motion of the wooden grip. Marks on the iron read, "Thos. Clark's Warranted Crimping Machine".
From the Servos Collection. A wooden box with iron lever used for twisting thread. The gear wheel is inserted into the wooden case, the handle is missing on the crank.
From the Servos Collection off of Mrs. Hannah Frey's Property. A large spoon or ladle made from horn.

This is an iron lock mechanism that is a flintlock for a military pistol. There are seven perforations and markings include "1812", "2", and a rampant lion presenting the crown. This flintlock is from the Servos Collection.

From the Servos Collection. Ice skates made from wooden platforms with steel blades and leather straps. The skates screw into the heel of the boot as well as having toe plates. The straps attach to the heel and toe as well. The skates were manufactured by the Moulson Brothers, Union Works, Sheffield.

From the Servos Collection. An iron coffee mill with a possible copper lip and iron handle with wooden grip. There is a void in the front of the mill that would fit a drawer and two tabs on the sides with holes for the ability to attach the mill to a flat surface by nails.Another coffee mill in the collection: FA69.3.122

A coffee bean grinder from the Servos Collection. This coffee grinder hosts a cast iron bowl and wooden base. The bowl has a handle extending from the centre to allow for the grinding of coffee beans. The wooded base houses a drawer to catch the ground coffee and allow for an easy process of removing the coffee. There are illegible remains of a label on the inside of the drawer that reads, "...ERICAN EAGLE ...ILL."

A wrought iron apple peeler from the Servos Collection. The peeler has an iron handle with wooden knob, wing nut screw to attach to a table or other flat surface and crank gears to peel the apple. The manufacture marks are, "MFR'D BY C.E. HUDSON", "LEOMINSTER, MASS", "PAT. JAN 24, 1882".

A crimping iron with two rods from the Servos Collection. The stand has a wooden base with twisted iron mid-section that holds the iron. There are two iron rods, both with wooden handles and a larger iron end to fit inside the opening at the top of the stand. This type of iron was used for crimping material.

A copper cream skimmer from the Servos Collection. The skimmer would be used by hand to run over the top of the cream to remove unwanted fat from the milk. One end of the skimmer is pierced, likely to hang for storage on a nail or by attaching string.
An iron from the Servos Collection. This style of iron is known as a 'sad' or 'flat iron' and is made with an attached wrought iron handle.
From the Servos Collection. An oblong wicker basket with two bail handles. The basket is a cream brown and dark brown with marks, "1 2 F F 7" on the inside.
From the Servos Collection. A beige, brown basket with purple bands. Fixed with two bail handles with a hasp fastening to keep the basket closed.

This is a lock mechanism that was made for a tower musket. This lock mechanism was converted to percussion. There are four perforations and markings include "Tower", a tri-corn crown with the "GR" cipher underneath, and a "B" with an arrow pointing left.

From the Servos Collection. A large copper kettle used to boil water. The curved handle is attached by four copper rivets. The spout is attached with the seam brazed. There are four dots in a line under the handle, which may be a type of marking.

A copper tea kettle from the Servos Collection. This oval shapped copper tea kettle is fixed with a handle and 'S' bent spout. The handle is of solid constrution with a circular hand grip. The handle has the mark "3" on the innner side. The lid can be removed from the kettle and on the underside are the markings, "5/-POT 10". There are other designs on the bottom of the kettle.

From the Servos Collection. A circular copper steamer consisting of a pot and perforated lid. The pot sides are grooved and the two handles are attached using eight copper rivets. A wooden knob handle is attached to the top of the lid to remove it when hot.

A small teakettle from the Servos Collection. This small copper kettle is fixed with a handle, spout, and a larger circular base. The handle is attached to the body of the kettle by four rivets and has a wooden grip at the top to allow for handling when the kettle is hot. The lid can be removed with a small wooden knob. Both grip and knob on the kettle show remains of black paint. There are two large holes in the side of the kettle.

From the Servos Collection. A brass steamer with spout and curved handle. The steamer has a removeable perforated lid with soldered hoop handle. The steamer sides graduate allowing the lid to sit halfway down the height of the steamer. There is a large loop handle attached to the outside to allow pouring with a semi circle lid to contain liquid when pouring. Maker marks on the bottom of the steamer are, "BROMOMINERAL,TORONTO".

A kettle from the Servos Collection. This large copper kettle is fixed with a handle and 'S' bent spout. The handle is attached with four copper rivets and has a larger circular copper grip at the top. The lid can be removed with a copper knob on the top that is decorated with small circles.

From the Servos Collection. A large copper coffee urn with a recessed top and bottom. There are two handles that are attached by four copper rivets. There is a bronze tap/spout. The marks read, "GOOD AND MOORES, BUFFALO, N.Y.".

From the Servos Collection. A large copper kettle that is situated on a copper stand. The kettle has a protruding spout and recurved handle with wooden hand grip. The kettle would have been made with a handle but it has broken off. The lid has a steam vent and a wooden button handle. The inside of the lid and kettle have been tinned. The stand is also made of brass an in an oblong shape. Four feet in a pattern that curves upwards hold the kettle in place. There is a hole in the center of the stand for a spirit lamp.

From the Servos Collection. A cruet stand on a round base with five rings for condiment bottles. Their is a large fan shaped handle for easy manuvering around the dinner table. Typical condiments would have included, salt and pepper shakers or bottles of vinegar and olive oil.
An English prismatic type of flintlock that measures 3.7cm x 2.5cm. It belongs to the Servos Collection and was found at Niagara.

From the Servos Collection. A decanter with a screw cap lid and a spout that also has a screw cap attached with chain. The octagonal body has a lift ring handle. Marks on the lid include, a crest of a "5" with two shovels crossing underneath, and another crest with markings "F.V." with a flower underneath; both crests are inside a shield shape. Under the spout is the engraving "A.H. 1836" surrounded by a pattern with a shovel shape in the middle.

This is a round pewter plate, dated from the early 1800s. Markings on the plate include three cartouches, an angel with sword in one, and a hand and scales in the other leaning on a shield with a rampant lion. There is also a plant with three flowers on one side of the figure.
From the Servos Collection. A serving pitcher with wide mouth and formed spout. The handle has been applied and the body is turned with bands.

A pewter basin from the Servos Collection. This basin is has a lip around the outside and is decorated with an inside circle at the bottom. On the edge of the basin in script is written, "L. Tzohme Az Paschn - 1851". On the bottom of the basin is a stamp with three shields joined at the top. Each shield has a different image inside: 1) open hand with palm up; 2) rosette; 3) female figure with garland.

A pewter plate from the Servos Collection. A large plate with turned edges and rim. On the rim are the marks, "J.S." (possibly John Servos). The bottom is stamped with two shields with trees and the initials S.R., a third shield has a lattice design.

From the Servos Collection. A pewter beaker or cup with a turned rim. There is a repair on the bottom done from lead and has left some uneven spots. There are marks on the sides, "18.L'LT.56". Stamped on the bottom there are two shields, one with "1838" the other with a female running with a garland.
From the Servos Collection. A pewter sugar bowl with ivy leaf apron forming four feet. The bowl has an etched decoration on the body with two protruding bow handles.

From the Servos Collection. A walnut cruet stand with six egg cups on dowels. The ring handle encircles and acorn shaped centerpiece. The cruet sits on a circular base with three round feet. There is one egg cup missing.
This wrought iron tomahawk head from the Servos Collection also featuring a pipe bowl on the opposite end.
This brass candlestick features pewter decoration in scroll and acanthus design. There are small traces of possible silver plating.
A wrought iron French-style axe head from the Servos collection.

A one dollar note from the Servos Collection. The note has many different texts. The top says, "Payable at the Bank" two large "1" in circles are found under this with, "Five Shillings" on the inside of the circle. There is an image in the centre of the suspension bridge from Queenston, Ontario to Lewiston, New York. Under the image are the words, "The Niagara Suspension Bridge." There is other illegible writing and the date of 1840. The signature is likely that of the bank manager at Queenston.The second is a One Dollar / Five Shillings note from the "District of Wellington - Province of Canada". There is an image of a man on a horse waving his hat. The writing in cursive reads, "Promise to pay William Cook or Bearer ____ Years after the date at the office of the treasurer in Guelph and not elsewhere the sum of FIVE SHILLINGS. Currency with ____ Years Interest for value Received. No. ____ Guelph ____ 18__." The note has not been filled out and therefore is unissued.

This is a plate that would have been attached to a soldier's cross belt. It is oval shaped with a rough upper surface.  There are no clear markings on the inscribed. The reverse side has two knob-like buttons and a hook attached. Further research by Glen Smith in 2010 suggests it is potentially American officers cross belt plate from 1812.

A candlestick from the Servos Collection. This candlestick has a cast iron octangonal base with a brass top. The base is decorated with a pattern and the shaft is that of a hand holding a torch with the candle acting as the flame.

A pot from the Servos Collection. This pot is made from brass and has a large, iron bail handle. The handle is attached on two sides by copper rivets. The pot is decorated with a rolled edge and circular lines on the inside and bottom.

A pot from the Servos Collection. This pot is made from brass and has a large, iron bail handle. The handle is attached on two sides by copper rivets. The pot is decorated rolled edge giving it a nice finish.
From the Servos Collection. An oblong footstool with perforations on top for lifting. There is a curved apron design on both sides with solid feet at either end.
From the Servos Collection. A stoneware lid for a large crockpot. Decorated with pastoral figures (raised) & blue lattice design around the edge, under a glaze. The top cones to a knob type handle.
From the Servos Collection. A clay jar or pot with a rough glaze and red paint.Another jar from the collection: FA69.3.190
An iron padlock from the Servos Collection.

From the Servos Collection. A hand blown bottle with curved lip mouth. There is an oval pattern in the glass on each side with a pontil mark. There are two of the same bottle (FA69.3.191(B)) that fit inside a box (FA69.3.191(C)).

From the Servos Collection. A hand blown bottle with curved lip mouth. There is a pattern on the lip and also a chip. There are two similar bottles (FA69.3.191(A)) that fit inside a box (FA69.3.191(C)).
No Description Available

This tin candle lantern from the Servos Collection. The lantern  has a double strap handle. The door is perforated and has a wire to fasten it shut. The front is clear glass to let the light shine out. The top has a hole for smoke just under the handle. On the inside is a well for the candle stick to fit into so it stands erect.

From the Servos Collection. A square tin candle lantern with silvered reflecting disk. The base is perforated in a circle. There is an iron bail handle on the top and a back door with a strap handle. Three sides have glass (2 are missing) for light to shine. The candle stick sits in a holder that is atop a removable tray.

Featured in "100 Years, 100 Artefacts" Dr. Richard Merritt describes the box as, "A utilitarian object of impeccable local provenance, superb craftsmanship in original condition - what more could one ask for?This walnut box, 30 cm in height arrived at the museum in 1980 as part of the Servos Collection transferred from Parks Canada, having been obtained from the last member of the Servos Family at Palatine Hill on the Four Mile Creek.This late 17th - early 18th century box was designed to hold and conceal valuable papers/documents, perhaps a small Bible, coins, medals, jewellery, miniature family portraits and other treasured keepsakes - now long forgotten.The square-domed lid of the box contains a secret compartment.  Below, the front opens by a concealed peg revealing 2 rows of small drawers, behind one of which is a smaller hidden compartment.  The hand-forged iron lock and escutcheon plus hinges are fastened with early rose-headed nails.The Servos family was living during the late 1600s in the German Palatinate where it is thought the box originated.  The patriarch of the North American family arrived in the Province of New York on the Charlotte River in 1726 with a letter of introduction, probably kept in the box.During the American Revolution, four Servos brothers remained loyal to the Crown with 2 brothers, Captain Daniel and Lieutenant Jacob serving with the British Indian Department.  They and their families arrived at Niagara as refuges in the early 1780s with only a few possessions, including the box.  Daniel operated grist and sawmills as well as a general store on the Four Mile Creek where he erected his home, Palatine Hill, the earliest surviving house in Niagara until it burned in 1950's.  What an odyssey."
From the Servos Collection. A long thatching fork that was formed from the natural fork of a branch. The fork would have been used to move large amounts of hay or straw.

Servos branding iron, wording on the iron, "J Servos 196lbs. U. Canada". Among the many artifacts photographed at Palatine Hill by Canadian Homes & Gardens in 1927 was a display of wooden and iron tools which had been used in the Servos grist mills (c.1783-1911). One of the largest iron tools was a branding iron used to mark the heads of wooden flour barrels to validate the weight, millerÕs name and mill location. The Loyalists brought many iron tools with them from the United States but it is clear that the Servos branding iron was made by a blacksmith in Upper Canada.
From the Servos Collection. Seven sleigh bells made of brass attached to a leather strap. Some bells on the strap are replacements. The first bell has "NS" engraved on it and the fourth has "SI".

From the Servos Collection. This is a two-handed flail that attaches the head to the shaft with leather thongs. These thongs have likely been replaced. The flail was used for agricultural work and more specifically, threshing crops.
From the Servos Collection. A hard wood bowl with a band around the outer edge.

From the Servos Collection. A wooden box painted brown. The box has a lid that is attached by four-screw hinges. There is a lock and keyhole on the front. The box is lined with old newspaper and a picture of "Davidson". The newspaper shows a date of 1858-1859. Markings on the back of the box show an anchor with "H.Z."
A barrel fragment of the end section of a rifle barrel, the sight is still attached. From the Servos Collection.

From the Servos Collection. A tin candle mold with twelve sections. There is a strap handle on the back that shows turned edges. A wire ring on is attached for hanging the mold.Other candle molds from the collection: FA69.3.212, FA69.3.260
This tin candle mold has 12 empty cylinders to make up to 12 candles at a time. The mold is from the Servos Collection.

From the Servos Collection. A circular tin container with one circular and six 'pie shaped' compartments inside. It has a lid with wire bail handle on top that attaches with a clasp.Other tins in the collection: FA69.3.215, FA69.3.216
A tin box from the Servos Collection. This oblong tin has a curved lid with attached wire loop handle. It is covered in green paint that has, "alligatored". The front has a faint floral design.

A tin box from the Servos Collection. This oblong tin was likely used for tea leaves. The tin has two compartments on the inside. The lid is attached with hinges and has a loop catch on the front; on the top is a loop handle. The entire tin is painted black.
A flintlock mechanism from the Servos Collection. This particular object was found on the Servos Farm.

From the Servos Collection. A brass fluted powder flask. It has four wire rings for attachment to a uniform. It has a measuring cap on top used for measuring the exact amount of powder for each shot. The markings on the flask, "A M", and on the spout "AMFLASK&CAP" with many numbers.

A cowbell from the Servos Collection. The sides of the bell are welded and riveted; handle welded, as well as the loop to hold the clapper. The clapper is a nut and makes a clear sound. The bell is undoubtedly homemade.

From the Servos Collection. A large metal cowbell. The cowbell is joined on each side with two rivets and welding. The handle attaches through slots and is welded from below. The clapper is roughly shaped but makes a loud and clear sound.
A cowbell from the Servos Collection. Joined at the sides by welding, no rivets; handle welded on from outside of the bell. The inside clapper is missing.

From the Servos Collection. A set of eyeglasses and case. The case is made of pewter and is ribbed and beaded with decoration. It is oblong shaped with two initials that have been scratched in, "OJ". The lining inside the case is felt. The glasses are made from copper attached to pewter by thread, with glass for the lens. The lens section is small and circular shaped with only one lens present. The marks on the glasses read, "Hofman".The glasses are in the collection under: FA69.3.227.2

Eyeglasses from the Servos Collection. These eyeglasses are housed in a pewter case with felt lining. The eyeglasses are made of pewter and copper and have glass lenses (one missing). The glasses are held together by thread and nails and are in very poor condition, with many period repairs. On one arm is the maker mark "HOFMAN".
From the Servos Collection. This seedbox was used as an easy container while spreading seed. It is kidney shaped, made from wood and had metal rings on the upper edge.
A flintlock mechanism from the Servos Collection. This particular object was discovered on the Servos Farm.
No Description Available
From the Servos Collection. A wrought iron axe head with hook. The axe would have been used for splitting lengths of wood.
From the Servos Collection. A hand-wrought iron door latch that is attach to a board by six square nails. The board has been cut and was undoubtedly part of a larger door at some point.

From the Servos Collection. Tanned leather girth with two beaded, steel stirrups. The Girth is pierced with 12 billet holes; has four leather strap loops and attached metal buckle. The two leather straps with metal buckles attached each have a metal stirrup. These were originally owned by Dr. Gammidge.

Featured in "100 Years, 100 Artefacts" Cam Calder describes the chair as, ". . .likely early nineteenth century and because of the more detailed turning and shape may have been imported.  It is of the Windsor design and shows how middle to upper class homes were furnished in the early 1800's.  The chair has seven splats and "hole and wedge" construction, although the seat is slightly narrower.  It came from the Servos collection." It is said to have been used in the First Parliament of Upper Canada.
From the Servos Collection. Two wooden (oak) hand fashioned wire brushes or combs.
From the Servos Collection. A pair of hand sewn, caramel suede, deer skin moccasins. These are plain in design with thong ties and cloth instep. There is no evidence of the moccasins being worn.

From the Servos Family Collection, a pair of deer skin moccasins. The pair are hand made with elaborate beaded patterns of flowers in shades of pink, red and rust with leaves in green, black and blue. It is possible that these moccasins originate from the Ojibwe.

A crimping machine from the Servos Collection. This green painted, cast iron crimping machine is made by T.&C. Clarke's & Co. It has brass knobs for adjustment to tension, turned wood handles, and four holes for screws to allow for attachments.

From the Servos Collection. A pine board stained and plained that houses eight chisels and two handles. The board has two metal screws on the top edge to allow for hanging on the wall. The board's face has been badly worn and a tanned leather strip is tacked on to allow tools to be hung. The eight chisels are of varying sizes and the two handles sit on either end.

This tin carriage lamp features a wing nut clamp for attachment. The lamp hosts a glass front with silvered reflecting disk at rear. Inside the lamp is a ventilation and fuel cap with a flax wick to hold a flame. The lantern is from the Servos Collection.

A cast iron circular three pount weight from the Servos Collection. The weight shows traces of black paint, as well as a "3" in the centre. The weight would have been used with a balance scale to weigh different commodities.
A cast iron circular two pound weight from the Servos Collection. The weight has traces of black paint and a large "2" in the centre. Likely used with a balance scale to weight different commodities.
From the Servos Collection. A double pulley made of wood. Wheels are housed on the inside, while a canvas loop encircles the block of wood.

A pulley from the Servos Collection. Made of wood and rope, this pulley is of sound construction. The rope is around the wooden housing, which hosts a wheel within. There is a broad arrow and "O" marked on the outside of the wood.

From the Servos Collection. A cast iron bit along with another bit for under the horses neck make up the metal parts of this bridle. A dark brown, rolled leather, stitched on strap make up the reins.Another bridle from the collection: FA69.3.248

From the Servos Collection. A wrought iron hammerhead that shows considerable use. The head shows a typical hole in the center that would house a handle. A replacement handle has been added to the hammer.
From the Servos Collection. A wrought iron chisel used on wood.
From the Servos Collection. A solid shot cannonball that has been split in half.

Part of the Servos Collection, and is listed as a British OfficerÕs waistcoat. It is more likely that it is a domestic waistcoat. There are eleven self-covered buttons, a cross pattern and quilted in curved lines. Ecru silk waistcoat, chain stitch quilted in diagonal wavy lines. Single breasted, standing band collar, 3" high, 12 half inch buttons. Fully lined in fine linen; back is madder red homespun, and red twill weave tape. Centre front length is 17 1/2"

While most samplers were completed under the supervision of the women in the family, some were done while attending school. Within the collection we have only one sampler that proves it was completed while attending a formal education. This sampler is part of the Servos Family collection, and while the maker is not known, the name of the school, the Tochter Institute, is embroidered on it.

This outdoor, tin candle lantern has circular lenses on three of the sides. The lantern is perforated on all sides as well as the tented top. It has a circular handle on the top to ease carrying. The lenses are made from glass bottle bottoms. The lantern is from the Servos Collection.
A candle mold made of tin and pewter. This candle mold hosts twelve individual molds in three lines of four. The top and bottom have large rectangles to support the mold.
From the Servos Collection. A cast iron boot jack decorated by three hearts and five holes. The jack has two legs near the mouth to give it elevation for removing the boot.

From the Servos Collection. A wrought iron truck covered in hide (with hair intact). There are many studs covering the chest with wrought iron handles, lock and keyhole cover. The initials "I. D. S." are found on the top.Other trucks found in the collection: FA69.3.263, FA69.3.264, FA69.3.267.

A hide covered trunk from the Servos Collection. The trunk hosts iron studs and industrial style wrought iron handles. The lock on the front of the trunk has been crudely removed, likely to get to the contents inside. The inside of the trunk in lined with decorative paper.

A small hide covered trunk from the Servos Collection. The trunk is covered in hide and attached with studs. There are metal plates and hinges also found on the trunk. The inside is not covered and the wood is exposed.

From the Servos Collection. A bed or reclining chair, hinged with a curved head and foot, the seat, back, and footrest have strapping to hold a mattress. The bed has two arms and four fixed legs, it also has traces of black paint.

Young girls were expected to grow up, get married, have children and care for their family home. These expectations meant that girls often received a very different education then boys. Girls were often taught only arithmetic or reading-if their parents could afford to pay for their schooling-along with other skills that were considered to be "female accomplishments". This included manners, sewing, painting, music and comportment. Samplers are therefore the most tangible evidence of female education during the early years of Niagara history. To prepare a young girl for the responsibility of sewing for her future family, girls completed at least two samplers. The first, called a marking sampler, was completed when a girl was around 5 or 6 (sometimes older) and served two purposes: to teach basic embroidery and numbers and the alphabet. A wonderful example of a marking sampler within our collection is this one made by Mary Miller Ball at the age of 8 years. If you take a close look at Mary Miller's sampler, what designs catch the eye? Letters or birds? Anything else? While it is not the most visually appealing or even the best quality in terms of skill, what one should notice is how the alphabet repeats on Mary's sampler. I am sure that many people can remember practicing their own handwriting skills in elementary school by writing the letters of the alphabet over and over again. On this sampler Mary embroidered the alphabet twice to show she had learned it. The sewing skills and education that Mary learned via this sampler would have no doubt benefited her later in her life. After marrying into the Servos family, and divorcing her husband, Mary ended up raising her 4 children at the Four Mile Creek Mills. She also managed the family business, kept meticulous records, managed all of her own affairs, lived on her own means and owned all the stock and chattels on the farm. The sampler provided her with a means of practicing literacy and numbers, skills greatly needed to manage a business.
Part of the Servos Family Collection, this small wooden trunk is covered with an animal hide. There are iron handles and a lock plate. It is lined with white paper that is has blue polka dots.
From the Servos Collection. A ramrod guide for a British Tower flint-lock musket that was discovered in Niagara.

From the Servos Collection. A spool bed, twin size with the head and foot boards of the same height. The bottom is made of slats and head and end boards have six posts each with tapered posts.Other parts of this bed in the collection: FA69.3.270.1(B), FA69.3.270.1(C), FA69.3.270.1(D), and another bed: FA69.3.270.1(A-D), FA69.3.281, FA69.3.282
From the Servos Collection. A wrought iron toaster with hinged iron shaft and heart shaped handle. The toaster is made up of six twisted wire brackets to hold the bread slices.
A basin from the Servos Collection. This metal basin has a flared lip and solid one-peice construction. It sits on three circular button legs.

From the Servos Collection. This is a fragment of a triangular bayonet blade, dated from the War of 1812-1814, that was discovered in the Niagara River. A bayonet is a steel blade that is designed to fit on the muzzle of a rifle or musket barrel, making it into a close range weapon. This would have been on arguably every soldier's firearm during the War of 1812-1814.
No Description Available

In its early period, coverlets were made in the home by women who used narrow looms to produce simple geometric designs, these are known as overshot coverlets. One such coverlet in the collection is this one and it was made in two panels and seamed at the centre. Unfortunately, there is no attribution to a weaver, but we do know that it has a connection to the Servos family who owned and operated the Four Mile Mills from early settlement until around the turn of the 20th century. While the mills they operated were saw and grist, the family tried to broaden their scope of operations to offer a variety of services including, blacksmiths, brewers, wagon makers and weavers. Women of the Servos family often participated in the daily operation of the mills, including Elizabeth Servos who helped with the families weaving operation. Perhaps, Elizabeth wove this overshot coverlet.

In its early period, coverlets were made in the home by women who used narrow looms to produce simple geometric designs, these are known as overshot coverlets. This coverlet in the collection is made from undyed cotton or linen and blue wool and was made in two panels and seamed at the centre. Unfortunately, there is no attribution to a weaver, but we do know that it has a connection to the Servos family who owned and operated the Four Mile Mills from early settlement until around the turn of the 20th century. While the mills they operated were saw and grist, the family tried to broaden their scope of operations to offer a variety of services including, blacksmiths, brewers, wagon makers and weavers. Women of the Servos family often participated in the daily operation of the mills, including Elizabeth Servos who helped with the families weaving operation. Perhaps, Elizabeth wove this overshot coverlet.
From the Servos Collection. An oval wooden footstool with four spindle legs painted black. The top is covered in fabric and has a floral design of green and black.

From the Servos Collection. A tin coffee bean roaster, painted black and consisting of four parts. The first part is a stand with a hole for heading the device. The second, a bowl for supporting a mesh cylinder where the beans would be heated. Third, the mesh wire container for rotating the beans, it is curved and has a handle of wood. Lastly a circular lid with wooden knob handle to keep the heat contained. Marks on the coffee roaster are, "Patent J.S. Wien".

From the Servos Collection. This is a bayonet socket with a small portion of the blade attached that was discovered in the Niagara River. A bayonet is a steel blade that is designed to fit on the muzzle of a rifle or musket barrel, making it into a close range weapon. This would have been on arguably every soldier's firearm during the War of 1812-1814.

This is a bayonet socket with a portion of the blade attached that was discovered in the Niagara River. A bayonet is a steel blade that is designed to fit on the muzzle of a rifle or musket barrel, making it into a close range weapon. This would have been on arguably every soldier's firearm during the War of 1812-1814. Research in 2010 suggests this is a British Bayonet.
From the Servos Collection. This bayonet, dated 1812-1814, has a triangular blade. It was recovered from the Niagara River in 1980. Research by Glen Smith in 2010 suggests it is U.S. bayonet.

From the Servos Collection. A wine red woven sash made from silk like material. The sash has fringed ends and a woven loop. This is the sash worn by Col. Peter Servos, Guard of Honour for the Prince of Wales (Later King Edward VII).
From the Servos Collection. Two hand sewn black felt epaulets on a wooden frame. They are trimmed with gold braid and silver plated. Each has a hook.
From the Servos Collection. Two epaulets with braid trim and metal clasps. Each epaulet is marked "British Militia".

From the Servos Family Collection. Earlier Society records state that this bugle was used in the War of 1812.  Markings on the bugle, "JOHN G. KLEMM, PHILADELPHIA" suggest it was used by American forces.  Recent research indicates that the date is more likely 1850-1870, as Klemm manufactured brass instruments in Philadelphia that were used during the Civil War.
From the Servos Collection. A brass candlestick with candle height adjuster and candle ejector.

A horn drinking cup which once belonged to the Servos family. On close examination this beaker proved to be of turned wood, well polished to emulate horn, with an inset wood base. It is lined with sterling silver, the rim bearing a scalloped pattern. This rim bears hallmarks which indicate that it was manufactured by the firm of George Ashforth and Company of Sheffield, England between 1773 and 1783.
The origin of the cup and where and how the silver lining was added is a mystery. Ashforth was mainly known for the manufacture of such items as tea and coffee pots, candlesticks and salt cellars; so it is strange to find a beaker lined with their silver. One conjecture might be that the lining was part of a flat silver piece, while the rim was adapted from a small item such as a salt cellar.
Since the Loyalist Servos brothers came to Niagara from Schoharie, New York in 1778, it may be assumed that the cup came into their possession after the American Revolution. Whether it was before they moved to Ontario is unknown. It is purported to have belonged to Jacob Servos who settled north of the present Lakeshore Road.

From the Servos Collection. A wooden Jewellery Box inlaid with mother of pearl and silver; the key hole is also mother of pearl. The box is lined with rose silk on the inside of the lid and rose paper in the box. There is a brass lock and green baize on the bottom of the box.
From the Servos Collection. A brass candlestick with large tray base. The candlestick has a candle adjuster and handle attached.

From the Servos Collection. A portable desk or writing chest possibly made from walnut. The desk is ornamented with brass mountings. The desk hosts an ink well and quill box both set in brass and a black painted well for writing utensils. Inside the lid is lined with blue watered silk and the letter box lined with white. There is a small drawer in the front with a brass pull to open it. The box is supported by four feet, painted black. A note in the front drawer reads, "John Drase & Mary Elizabeth Olivia Josephine / Eldest Son & Youngest (Child) ? / Peter Claus & Mary Ball Servos".
From the Servos Collection. A candlestick holder, looks as though it is possibly homemade and well used for practicle purposes.

From the Servos Collection. A tan leather covered case or portable desk. The writing surface is covered with mulberry velvet. The box houses two compartments and a pouch on one side and a slot on the other. There is a lock on the box that is made from brass and has the markings "Patent Patent". On the back side of the desk there is writing in black ink, "C. Camidge, Esq., Peto & Co., Crimea, Passenger for London".Additional research suggests that "Peto & Co." was the firm headed by Samuel Morton Peto (1809-1889). He was a major railway builder and built a railway from Balaclava to Sebastopol to carry supplies during the Crimean War. It is possible that 'C. Camidge' was working for Peto's firm in Niagara during the construction of the early railways. It is believed that this is Charles Camidge who worked for the Peto firm as paymaster and came to Canada to assist with railroad development. He settled in Niagara, taught at a local school (see Janet Carnochan's History of Niagara). Camidge was accused of harming a young girl from Maria Rye's school for British girls called "Our Western Home" and went to trial in St. Catharines. We are unsure of the outcome but in his later years, he shot himself in his home on King street.

From the Servos Collection. A Candle snuffer from this period is a scissor-like tool used to trim the wick of a candle. This tool was rendered obsolete when self-snuffing wicks were introduced in the late-eighteenth and early-nineteenth centuries.

From the Servos Collection. A Candle snuffer from this period is a scissor-like tool but, instead of having blades that cut, the snuffers have a small box and a plate for snuffing out the flame of a candle.

From the Servos Collection. A Candle snuffer from this period is a scissor-like tool but, instead of having blades that cut, the snuffers have a small box and a plate for snuffing out the flame of a candle.

From the Servos Collection. A walnut chest that is also a portable desk. It has brass-bound edges, centre plate, recessed handles and keyhole plate. The inside writing surface is covered with green felt. The marks "W.B." are engraved into the centre plate on the top.

Wooden pencil box with lid that slides nicely into grooves along the edge of the box. Painted a dark brown with a small compartment to store pencils. The marks "D'ALMAINE NIAGARA" are found on the box. It is possible the box may be related to D'Almaine who was an early artist of Niagara.

From the Servos Collection. A black leather and felt shako. The visor and crown are made from black leather. There is braided trim on the crown with two ventilating buttons. A metal slot is present to hold the plume. On the front is a silver Maltese cross insignia, surmounted by a crown. The marks read, "Lincoln Scots".

From the Servos Collection. A British military black leather bullet pouch. Two tin-lined compartments would have housed the ammunition. There is a button clasp that holds the lid down. The marks on the box are, "B" with a broad arrow pointing upwards, "52", "1049", "1", and "1857".

From the Servos Collection. An instrument used to light candles. It is equipped with a wooden handle and lead pan that can be covered and has a small hole at the end used to light the candle with a small flame. There are marks that read, "FR  J.A. Freel"
From the Servos Collection. A tin candle lantern in the "Bull's Eye" design. The lantern has wire handles and is build to swivel to shut out the light.

From the Servos Collection. A hand carved handle with leather thong and copper pan. The pan is decorated on the lid by an engraving. This bed warming pan was used by Ranger John Clement as a frying pan during military campaigns of 1776.

From the Servos Collection. This tool was used to carry small amounts of coal that would supply an indoor coal stove or heater. This coal scuttle is made from tin with an iron handle. The lid can be lifted with a loop handle to allow the coal to enter and exit.

From the Servos Collection, this tea caddy would have been used to store lose tea leaves inside the home. This caddy shows four paw style feet and a small knob on the hinged lid. A keyhole is present on the front. There are traces of black and orange paint on the exterior giving some idea of the design.

The rare art of tea drinking has been celebrated for centuries. Tea was such a valued commodity it was traded as we might trade petroleum today; the term "under lock and key" may be applied to give us an idea of how valued this consumable luxury was to our forbearers. In a household of great means the master or mistress would hold a key, as would a senior and trusted member of staff. The ceremony would begin with the caddy being opened to reveal a silver foil lined compartment or compartments and in some cases a crystal mixing bowl. This bowl was used to blend the exotic teas. When the tealeaves were considered to have been well used, or simply spent, the "slop" would return to the pantry or kitchens, where it would be stretched by the lesser mortals of the household for a much weaker mug of tea.

From the Servos Collection. The spice tin held the spices for the family. This tin is oblong in shape and has a hinged lid with wire loop handle. There is evidence of a red, green and yellow floral pattern done in lacquer.

From the Servos Collection. A cast iron cauldron that would have had many uses, including boiling water and soups over the fire. This cauldron has a wire bail handle and a lid with loop handle.Another cauldron from the collection: FA69.3.220

From the Servos Collection. This cast iron griddle would have been used to cook or warm many things over a fire. The grill on top is attached with a single rivet in the middle which gives the ability to swivel the food. The griddle is marked with, "Brooks & Patton, Columbus Ohio" "9 & 10".

From the Servos Collection. A tin roasting pan that would typically be used to roast meat. The 'pan' is more of a tent shape and has two tin strap handles on the outside. Inside there are three wire hooks attached to a rod that runs along the top.

From the Servos Collection. A circular cast iron flat-iron holder with wire bail handle. The marks on the iron include, "PAT.", "OCT 18 1864", "J.M.B. DAVIDSON & CO." and "ALBANY, N.Y.". The iron holder would have been used to house irons that were still hot. This would give them time to cool down without damaging the surface.

From the Servos Collection. This cast iron waffle maker has two parts, the lid and base. The lid attaches to the base with two hinges and is able to close down on top. There are four section to the waffle maker. The makers mark is, "Books & Patton, Columbus, Ohio".

From the Servos Collection. A pair of foot warmers with hinged tops. Enclosed is a spirit lamp. The warmers have perforated top and base with a small glass window. The foot warmers would have been filled with a material that kept heat and put of a steady warming for the feet.
From the Servos Collection. A hand carved wooden leveler. Has a circular hole along side an oblong hole, used as a hand grip. This would have been used in the first Servos Mill, built in 1791.
From the Servos Collection. A wooden rolling pin. One end of the pin has been perforated for a cord. It was property of Mrs. Hannah Frey (1784-1834).
From the Servos Collection. A wooden ladle with birch knot bowl. It has a notation on the bottom of the bowl that reads, "Birch knot bowl, made with crooked knife by indians".

From the Servos Collection. A hardwood (maple) masher with handle. It is perforated at the end of the handle for hanging. The body of the masher is carved with pointed grooves. The masher is associated with Mrs. H. Frey (1758-1834).

From the Servos Collection. A wooden 'butter bowl' used in the house to keep butter fresh and of a spreadable consistency. This bowl has four holes which were likely intended to hold wire for a handle.

From the Servos Collection. A hardwood (birch) mortar and pestle set. The mortar has larger aesthetic rings on the top and bottom, gradually widening from the base. The pestle is double headed to make mashing/grinding easier.
A mill spice from the Servos Collection. The mill hosts an iron hinged handle with wooden knob that is turned to grind spices. Brought from Germany in 1726 by Christopher Servos.

From the Servos Collection. This is a small ladle that would have been used in the house to make butter pats for the table from a larger block of butter stored in the butter bowl. This particular ladle was owned by Mrs. Hannah Frey (1758-1834).

From the Servos Collection. This bag holder would have been used in the First Servos Mill, built in 1791. The bag holder was used by one man to ensure the opening to the bag was accessible. There is a bar to hold on to and a spike on one end indicating it may have been driven into something to support itself.
A wooden bag holder from the Servos Collection. There would have been spikes on the end for bags. There are carved zig-zag patterns on the bar.
From the Servos Collection. A hand carved birch grain shovel, would have been used in the First Servos Mill, built in 1791. A similar grain shovel in the collection: FA69.3.82.

A grain shovel from the Servos Collection. This shovel was used in the First Servos Mill, Built in 1791. The large mouth of th shovel would have been used to obtain large amounts of grain with every scoop. The sturdy handle makes it very efficient to move large amounts of grain in a short amount of time.

From the Servos Collection. A hand carved bootjack (or boot pull) was used to remove boots without the owner bending over and manually removing them. One would stick their heel into the semi-circle and pull back and up, removing his foot from the boot.
From the Servos Collection. A hand carved wooden ladle with a wide bowl mouth.Another similar ladle in the collection: FA69.3.85
A hand carved butter ladle from the Servos Collection.

From the Servos Collection. A hand carved wooden butter dish or bowl. It is oval in shape and shows significant signs of use. There is a large crack on one side that has been period repaired with large iron staples.Another butter bowl from the collection: FA69.3.259.
From the Servos Collection. Milk would have been poured into the larger opening and a sieve added to the smaller opening to strain the milk. Came from Mrs. Hannah Frey's (1758-1834) property.
From the Servos Collection. A hand wrought steel tray with rolled rims and hand holds on each end. This tray was brought from Germany in 1726 by Christopher Servos.
From the Servos Collection. A small cast iron pot with bail handle and three tapered feet. The cauldron would have been placed directly over or in the fire to heat different liquids.

From the Servos Collection. A wrought iron tea kettle that is decorated by three knob feet and an ornamented handle. It has a lid, with a knob on the top for removing. The kettle has a large hole in the side from rust damage.
From the Servos Collection. A cast iron spud or chisel. It is possible the handle may have also been used as a pick.
From the Servos Collection. A wrought iron pot hook. This hook would have been used to hang cauldrons or pots from the fireplace crane over the fire.
From the Servos Collection. A wrought iron set of tongs used for work in the fireplace. The togs have knob handles with long arms and a bend at the end of the arms for grabbing and moving.
From the Servos Collection. A brass ladle with curved handle and wooden grip. Used for day to day household cooking; likely used with the cauldron.

From the Servos Collection. A ladle used for straining. The ladle has an iron handle and brass bowl. The bowl is attached to the handle by two rivets and is perforated for the job of straining. The handle has a hole at the end for hanging.

From the Servos Collection. A small oval sad iron with curved handle. The sad or flat iron consisted of a handle and solid, heavy base used for smoothing clothes.Other (triangular) irons from the collection: FA69.3.98, FA69.3.127
An iron from the Servos Collection. This iron is triangular with a curved handle. There are traces of black paint found on the surface of the iron.

From the Servos Collection. A large wrought iron fork. The fork has 3 prongs at the end as well as a handle with a hole in it for hanging. There are marks on the handle that read, "H.M. or W.H.". The fork was likely used with the fireplace to move around wood.

An oval military pill box cap with piping on top. Beige piping and beige band on the outside with a dark red leather sweat band and brown leather strap on the inside. The hat came out of the Servos collection.

Tanned leather wallet with 3 lined compartments (blue and white cardboard). Metal clasp is engraved and has thumb latch. Wallet carried by Capt. Daniel Servos during War of American Revolution. Numerous indecipherable inscriptions in ink. One date legible, 21 August,1827. Includes a blue silk ribbon.

Pair of brass shoulder scales epaulettes. There are 13 scales per epaulets, sewn to a leather mounting strap. A note is with the epaulettes that reads, "Service epaulettes worn by Capt. Daniel Servos during war of American Revolution". It is also possible these are chin straps for a helmet: not epaulettes, as they are quite small.
